FIGREF1.text: surgeons in New York City, we are currently in the epicenter of the COVID-20 19 crisis in the United States. As of April 24, 2020, there are 869,172 COVID-19 cases in the 21 United States of which over 600,000 are in New York City. Mount Sinai Health System has one 22 of the largest consortiums of COVID-19 patients in New York City. To meet the demand of the 23 2 increasing numbers of hospitalized patients with COVID-19, many healthcare providers have 1 been placed in roles outside of their immediate level of training and are often treating a large 2 cohort of patients. In part, this has resulted in a sharp increase in the rate of central line 3 complications resulting in urgent vascular surgery consultation and intervention. 4The etiology for complications following central line insertion is likely multifactorial.

FIGREF2.text: Ultrasound-guided access has been shown to decrease central line complications.1-2 Emergent 6 line insertion and placement by an inexperienced practitioner also increases central line 7 complications. 3 ICUs are at full capacity with critically-ill COVID-19 patients. These errors 8 following central line insertions will also result in increased exposure of the virus to frontline 9 healthcare workers from the work-up, imaging, and intervention needed to manage these 10 complications. 11 In response to this, we have created a line service team to assist with all central and 12 arterial line placements at Mount Sinai Hospital. However, the COVID-19 pandemic brings 13 important challenges and considerations to central line placements which are patient and 14 institution specific and will alter treatment algorithms. We discuss some of these considerations of the line service team should be tailored to the specific institution 19 depending on availability of staff and volume of access consults. Our line service team consists 20 of over 14 vascular surgeons, interventional radiologists, and 11 interventional cardiologists who 21 have extensive experience in ultrasound-guided vascular access. At our hospital, each shift has at 22 least two attendings and 1-2 nurse practitioners who all are in-house. Each shift is 12 hours and 23 the line service is available seven days a week. In order to contact the line team, there is a 1 centralized cell phone number that was distributed throughout the hospital. Currently, there are 2 approximately 5 -10 requests for line insertions per day at Mount Sinai Hospital which we expect 3 to significantly increase in the upcoming weeks. To date, all cases have been performed at 4 bedside, but a negative pressure room in a fluoroscopy suite is available for difficult line 5 insertions. The attending physician performs the procedure and a nurse practitioner is in the 6 patient room to assist with line placement. Under ultrasound guidance, the central line is inserted 7 in the usual fashion and secured with silk suture. Each port is instilled with heparinized saline 8 (5000u/cc) and a biopatch and sterile dressing are applied.

Futile line insertions will subject the staff to unnecessary 14 viral exposure as well as misallocation of limited medical supplies and personal protective 15 equipment (PPE). In particular, a significant portion of patients with severe COVID-19 disease 16 will develop renal failure requiring hemodialysis and the prognosis appears to be very poor. 5 17This is limiting available hemodialysis machines and exposing the dialysis staff to COVID-19.

FIGREF4.text: Thus, it is particularly important in these patients needing hemodialysis access that a goals of 19 care discussion is held prior to line insertion whenever possible. In non-intubated patients who 20 are hemodynamically stable, preference can be given to placement of midline catheters or large 21 bore peripheral intravenous access.

FIGREF5.text: team has one disposable premade bag for each central line that contains all 2 equipment needed, including PPE, ultrasound probe cover, and the central line kit. The 3 ultrasound machines are meticulously cleaned with an alcohol-based solution after every use. We 4 realize some institutions may have limited access to ultrasounds in which case anatomic 5 landmarks can be used. This will also avoid transporting and cleaning an ultrasound machine for 6 each procedure. Additionally, portable chest x-rays may be difficult to obtain in a timely fashion 7 during the COVID-19 crisis. An advantage of femoral vein access is no post-procedure chest x-8 ray is needed. However, for straightforward internal jugular vein central lines, post-procedure 9 chest x-rays are not routinely ordered to avoid potential exposure of the virus to radiology staff.

The majority of these high-risk for 16 aerosolization procedures have been in non-intubated patients with COVID-19 and renal failure 17 requiring hemodialysis access.
